snippet: At a time when the attribution of paintings can be so litigious, a startling reassessment provides a rare window into the often imprecise, and debate-riddled, field of identifying the authorship of artworks.
abstract: Artwork sold at Christie's auction in 2013, thought to be copy of work by 19th-century painter John Constable that sold for around $5,200, is reassessed as original work and later sold at Sotheby's auction for $5.2 million; startling jump in price and continuing question of provenance offers glimpse into often imprecise field of identifying authorship of artworks.

byline.contributor: Bryony Clarke contributed reporting from Hambleden, England.

lead_paragraph: At a time when the attribution of paintings can be so litigious, a startling reassessment provides a rare window into the often imprecise, and debate-riddled, field of identifying the authorship of artworks.

headline.seo: With Misattributed Constable Masterpiece, a Rare Look Into the Imprecise World of Art Identification
headline.main: $5,200 or $5.2 Million? It’s All in How It’s Framed
headline.print_headline: Art of a Flip: $5,200 to Millions
